text: October  2009
label: TITLE

text: Benefits of the Affordable Health Care for America Act
label: BODY

text: In the 4th Congressional District of Oregon
label: BODY

text: Committee on Energy and Commerce
label: BODY

text: The Affordable Health Care for America Act will make health care affordable for the middle class,
label: BODY

text: provide security for seniors, and guarantee access to health insurance coverage for the uninsured — while
label: BODY

text: responsibly reducing the federal deficit over the next decade and beyond.  This analysis examines the
label: BODY

text: benefits of the legislation in the 4th Congressional District of Oregon.  Congressman Peter A. DeFazio
label: BODY

text: represents the district.
label: BODY

text: In Congressman DeFazio’s district, the Affordable Health Care for America Act will:
label: BODY

text: • Improve employer-based coverage for 408,000 residents.
label: BODY

text: • Provide credits to help pay for coverage for up to 209,000 households.
label: BODY

text: • Improve Medicare for 137,000 beneficiaries, including closing the prescription drug donut hole
label: BODY

text: for 14,600 seniors.
label: BODY

text: • Allow 20,000 small businesses to obtain affordable health care coverage and provide tax credits
label: BODY

text: to help reduce health insurance costs for up to 18,300 small businesses.
label: BODY

text: • Provide coverage for 86,000 uninsured residents.
label: BODY

text: • Protect up to 1,200 families from bankruptcy due to unaffordable health care costs.
label: BODY

text: • Reduce the cost of uncompensated care for hospitals and health care providers by $78 million.
label: BODY

text: Affordable and Improved Health Care Coverage for the Middle Class
label: BODY

text: Better health care coverage for the insured.  Approximately 56% of the district’s population, 408,000
label: HH1

text: residents, receive health care coverage from their employer.  Under the legislation, individuals and
label: BODY

text: families with employer-based coverage can keep the health insurance coverage they have now, and it will
label: BODY

text: get better.  As a result of the insurance reforms in the bill, there will be no co-pays or deductibles for
label: BODY

text: preventive care; no more rate increases or coverage denials for pre-existing conditions, gender, or
label: BODY

text: occupation; and guaranteed oral, vision, and hearing benefits for children.
label: BODY

text: Affordable health care for the uninsured.  Those who do not receive health care coverage through their
label: BODY

text: employer will be able to purchase coverage at group rates through a health insurance exchange.
label: BODY

text: Individuals and families with an income of up to four times the federal poverty level — an income of up
label: BODY

text: to $88,000 for a family of four — will receive affordability credits to help cover the cost of coverage.
label: BODY

text: There are 209,000 households in the district that could qualify for these affordability credits if they need
label: BODY

text: to purchase their own coverage.
label: BODY

text: Coverage for individuals with pre-existing conditions.  There are 15,500 individuals in the district who
label: HH1

text: have pre-existing medical conditions that could prevent them from buying insurance.  Under the bill’s
label: BODY

text: insurance reforms, they will now be able to purchase affordable coverage.
label: BODY

text: Health care and financial security.  There were 1,200 health care-related bankruptcies in the district in
label: HH1

text: 2008, caused primarily by the health care costs not covered by insurance.  The bill caps annual out-of-
label: BODY

text: pocket costs at $5,000 for singles and $10,000 for families and eliminates lifetime limits on insurance
label: BODY

text: coverage, ensuring that no citizen will have to face financial ruin because of high health care costs.
label: BODY

text: Security for Seniors
label: BODY

text: Improving Medicare.  There are 137,000 Medicare beneficiaries in the district.  The health care reform
label: HH1

text: legislation improves Medicare by providing free preventive and wellness care, improving primary and
label: BODY

text: coordinated care, improving nursing home quality, and strengthening the Medicare Trust Fund.
label: BODY

text: Closing the Part D donut hole.  Each year, 14,600 seniors in the district hit the donut hole and are forced
label: BODY

text: to pay their full drug costs, despite having Part D drug coverage.  The legislation will provide these
label: BODY

text: seniors with immediate relief, covering the first $500 of donut hole costs in 2010, cutting brand-name
label: BODY

text: drug costs in the donut hole by 50%, and completely eliminating the donut hole by 2019.
label: BODY

text: Helping Small Businesses
label: BODY

text: Helping small businesses obtain health insurance.  Under the legislation, businesses with up to 100
label: HH1

text: employees will be able to join the health insurance exchange, benefitting from group rates and a greater
label: BODY

text: choice of insurers.  There are 20,000 small businesses in the district that will be able to join the health
label: BODY

text: insurance exchange.
label: BODY

text: Tax credits for small businesses.  Small businesses with 25 employees or less and average wages of less
label: BODY

text: than $40,000 will qualify for tax credits of up to 50% of the costs of providing health insurance.  There
label: BODY

text: are up to 18,300 small businesses in the district that could qualify for credits.
label: BODY

text: Covering the Uninsured
label: BODY

text: Coverage of the uninsured.  There are 122,000 uninsured individuals in the district, 20% of the district
label: BODY

text: residents under age 65.  The Congressional Budget Office estimates that nationwide, 96% of all
label: BODY

text: Americans will have insurance coverage when the bill takes effect.  If this benchmark is reached in the
label: BODY

text: district, 86,000 people who currently do not have health insurance will receive coverage.
label: BODY

text: Relieving the burden of uncompensated care.  In 2008, health care providers in the district provided
label: HH1

text: $78 million worth of uncompensated care.  This care was provided to individuals who lacked insurance
label: BODY

text: coverage and were unable to pay their bills.  Under the legislation, these costs of uncompensated care will
label: BODY

text: be virtually eliminated.
label: BODY

text: Deficit Responsibility
label: BODY

text: No deficit spending.  The cost of health care reform under the legislation is fully paid for:  half through
label: BODY

text: eliminating waste, fraud, abuse, and excessive profits for private insurers in Medicare and Medicaid and
label: BODY

text: half through a surcharge on the income of the top 0.3% wealthiest individuals.  This surcharge will affect
label: BODY

text: only 460 households in the district.  The surcharge will not affect 99.85% of taxpayers in the district.
label: BODY

text: Reducing the deficit.  According to the Congressional Budget Office, the bill will cut the deficit by over
label: BODY

text: $30 billion over the next decade and will continue to create a budget surplus over the next 20 years.
label: BODY

text: This analysis is based upon the following sources:  the U.S. Census (data on insurance rates and  small businesses); the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid
label: BODY

text: Services (data on Medicare and Part D enrollment) the Department of Health and Human Services (data on health care-related bankruptcies, uncompensated
label: BODY

text: care, and pre-existing conditions); and the House Committee on Ways and Means (data on the surtax).
label: BODY
